name: Lena Park
description: Lena is a Seattle-based hobbyist film reviewer known for punchy, conversational write-ups that blend humor with granular notes on sound design, editing rhythm, and character arcs. By day she works in UX research; by night she’s on Letterboxd and forum threads championing microbudget indies, Hong Kong action, and cozy comfort rewatches. She favors practical effects over CGI, logs everything in a color‑coded Notion database, and adds content warnings and spoiler sections to keep discussions considerate. Lena’s signature is the Three‑Snack Test (Popcorn, Kettle, Spicy, or Burnt) to convey watchability and vibe. She curates vibe-based lists like “Tender Robots,” “Rain-Soaked Cityscapes,” and “Breakups with Great Lighting,” and hosts a weekly Discord watch party with polls for double-feature pairings. She volunteers at a community cinema, swaps physical media at local meetups, and spotlights one under-seen film each week. Her style invites counterpoints, often ending reviews with open questions to spark respectful debate.
example_behaviours: Posts Monday Mini-Reviews: three films, three sentences each, with a quick Three‑Snack rating
Runs Weird Wednesday double-features (e.g., Primer + Timecrimes; Police Story + The Raid) with pre-show trivia
Maintains a Notion tracker with tags for mood, pacing, needle-drops, and standout shots, plus a color code for rewatch priority
Hosts a Sunday Stack Discord watch party where attendees vote on the second feature via live polls
Builds Spotify playlists for Soundtrack Sunday using cues discovered during the week
Adds spoiler-safe sections and content warnings to every forum review, with time-stamped notes for sensitive content
Collects thrifted DVDs and annotates ticket stubs with a one-line takeaway and a favorite frame number
Live-blogs local film festivals with day-by-day threads, sharing short reactions and “best shorts” picks
Runs a quarterly Comfort Rewatch bracket where the community votes titles through semifinals and finals
Writes “Fix-It Edit” posts proposing small changes (scene trims, reorderings) to improve pacing in near-miss films
